title: Nikhil Shah
text: This is my website. It currently contains two data visualization exercises.

title: Lichess.org
text:
This analysis uses data from the October 1, 2024 TidyTuesday.
This is a dataset of 20,058 online chess games. The data was collected and cleaned from Lichess.org by Kaggle/Mitchell J.

# adds a column that isolates the opening move of each game, and orders it by how common each move is
chess <- chess |>
  mutate(
    opening_move = ifelse(
      str_sub(moves, 1, 1)=='N', 
      str_sub(moves, 1, 3), 
      str_sub(moves, 1, 2)
      )
    ) |>
  mutate(
    opening_move = fct_infreq(opening_move)
    )

# creates a bar plot that shows the frequency of opening moves
chess |>
  ggplot() +
  geom_bar(aes(x = opening_move)) +
  labs(
    x = 'Opening Move',
    y = 'Number of Games',
    title = 'Frequency of opening moves for white on Lichess.com'
  )








This bar plot shows the frequency of initial moves in the dataset. e4 and d4 make up almost all of them. While knight to f3 is the third most popular, almost none of the games use knight to a3.


# A tibble: 20 × 3
   opening_move count proportion
   <fct>        <int>      <dbl>
 1 e4           12598    62.8   
 2 d4            4522    22.5   
 3 Nf3            725     3.61  
 4 c4             716     3.57  
 5 e3             416     2.07  
 6 g3             186     0.927 
 7 b3             173     0.862 
 8 f4             166     0.828 
 9 d3             131     0.653 
10 Nc3             99     0.494 
11 b4              88     0.439 
12 c3              56     0.279 
13 g4              38     0.189 
14 h4              33     0.165 
15 a4              28     0.140 
16 a3              27     0.135 
17 f3              23     0.115 
18 Nh3             15     0.0748
19 h3              14     0.0698
20 Na3              4     0.0199

title: National Park Species
text:
This analysis uses data from the October 8, 2024 TidyTuesday.
This is a dataset of species in American national parks, specifically the 15 most visited. The data is sourced from NPSpecies, a tool maintained by the National Park Service (NPS)’s Integrated Resource Management Applications (IRMA). It includes taxonomy information and other characteristics like sensitivities and rarity for each species found in each park.

species <- species |>
  filter(Family == 'Mustelidae') |>
  mutate(ParkName = str_replace(ParkName, ' National Park', '')) |>
  mutate(ParkName = fct_infreq(ParkName))

species |>
  ggplot() +
  geom_bar(aes(y = ParkName)) +
  labs(
    x = 'National Park',
    y = '# Species',
    title = 'Distinct species in family Mustelidae 15 national parks'
  )








This data displays the number of mustelid (weasels, badgers, otters) species in each of the 15 most visited national parks. This is because mustelids are my favorite taxon. I would have included my second-favorite taxon, pinnipeds (seals, sea lions, walruses), however I discovered there are none in any of the listed parks. The only conclusion I draw from this is that more people should visit Alaskan national parks.


# A tibble: 15 × 2
   ParkName              count
   <chr>                 <int>
 1 Glacier                   9
 2 Grand Teton               9
 3 Yellowstone               8
 4 Yosemite                  8
 5 Acadia                    7
 6 Great Smoky Mountains     7
 7 Olympic                   7
 8 Rocky Mountain            7
 9 Indiana Dunes             6
10 Cuyahoga Valley           5
11 Grand Canyon              4
12 Bryce Canyon              3
13 Hot Springs               3
14 Zion                      3
15 Joshua Tree               2
